formalpara.title: Figure 5:
formalpara.para: Gqα/Goα mutual inhibition through Gβ5/RGS complexes. This figure shows the components of the mutually inhibitory Gqα/Goα signaling pathways that operate in many C. elegans cells. The names of the genes encoding them are shown in parentheses. Elements in green (mAChR, Gqα, EGL-10 RGS, PLCβ, DAG, and IP3) promote Gqα signaling; elements in red (Goα, EAT-16 RGS, DAG kinase, and the hypothetical serpentine receptor that activates Goα) oppose Gqα signaling. Gβ5 (in blue) is necessary for the action of both RGSs. Reproduced, with permission, from Robatzek et al. (2001).
